content: I want to ask mathlib to print all the (known) instances of a type, say all the types that are known to mathlib to be an ordered semiring. Is this possible?

It's in the docs here: https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Order/Ring/Defs.html#OrderedSemiring if you expand the Instances: link -- does that look like what you're looking for?
If you have https://github.com/leanprover-community/batteries/blob/main/Batteries/Tactic/Instances.lean imported, you get the #instances command too
you should be able to write #instances OrderedSemiring or #instances OrderedSemiring _
Kent Van Vels has marked this topic as resolved.

As a somewhat related followup. Is there a way to print a hierarchy of types that would show that an Abelian group is a group? And that a ring has an associated additive group and an associated multiplicative monoid?
Kent Van Vels has marked this topic as unresolved.
I usually do this manually with variable (R : Type*) [Ring R] in #synth AddGroup R

I am envisioning something like the import_graph script, that makes a pdf of the import structure of mathlib. In what I am thinking, a directed edge would appear from the group node to commgroup node, because a commgroup is a group.

Has this been made? I don't have a need for it, but I would be interested in seeing it.
IIRC there was a partial picture of the graph of classes plus implications in the mathlib(3) paper
It's possible to do it approximately, but the full version is like asking if you can write a prolog program as a DAG. Typeclasses don't have a strict is-a relationship in the general case.
@Kevin Buzzard, thanks. I found a paper about mathlib3 and it indeed has part of the graph.
Sorry I wasn't more precise, I'm not at a computer right now. Glad you found it!
I was going to ask you for a citation, but then I thought you are busy enough, and it took me two seconds to find it.
Kent Van Vels has marked this topic as resolved.
